title: Cosmopolitan

contents.note: FictionMags (fiction contents of most issues up to 1963)

renewed-contributions.title: The Man Who Would Wreck the World
All in the Day's Work
renewed-contributions.note: Title as given in issue. CCE renewal record gives title as 'All in a Day's Work'.

renewed-contributions.title: He Had a Brother
renewed-contributions.note: CCE renewal record places this story in the June 1929 issue, but it actually ran in this issue.

renewed-contributions.title: A Prisoner in War
renewed-contributions.note: Title as given in issue. CCE renewal record gives title as 'A Prisoner of War'.

renewed-contributions.title: Here Comes a Sailor
renewed-contributions.note: Title as given in issue. CCE renewal record gives title as 'Scott in Love'. The story is a romance featuring a character named Scotto Freeman.

renewed-contributions.title: The Man Who Made His Mark
He Had a Brother
renewed-contributions.note: CCE renewal record places this story in this issue, but it actually ran in the May 1929 issue.

renewed-contributions.title: Stop Me if You've Heard This One
Jeeves and the Song of Songs
renewed-contributions.note: Title as given in CCE renewal record. The issue's table of contents gives the title as 'The Song of Songs', but the heading on the story's initial page spread also features the name 'Jeeves' prominently.

renewed-contributions.title: Artist's Model
renewed-contributions.note: Title as given in issue. CCE renewal record gives title as 'Portrait of the Artist's Wife'.

renewed-contributions.title: You Ought to See a Doctor
Mirage
renewed-contributions.note: CCE renewal record places this story in the January 1930 issue, apparently confusing it with 'A Marriage of Convenience', which appeared in that issue and also has a renewal record.

renewed-contributions.title: Jeeves and the Borrowed Dog
renewed-contributions.note: Title as given in CCE renewal record. The issue's table of contents gives the title as 'The Borrowed Dog', but the heading on the story's first page also features the name 'Jeeves' prominently.

renewed-contributions.title: Jeeves and the Love That Purifies
Jeeves and the Spot of Art
A Marriage of Convenience
renewed-contributions.note: CCE renewal record places this story in the October 1929 issue, apparently confusing it with 'Mirage', which appeared in that issue and also has a renewal record.

renewed-contributions.title: Jeeves and the Old School Chum
The Chronicles of Captain Blood, Pt. 1: The Blank Shot
The Chronicles of Captain Blood, Pt. 2: The Treasure Ship
Gala Night
renewed-contributions.note: Title as given in issue.  CCE renewal record gives title as 'Gala Nights'.

renewed-contributions.title: The Chronicles of Captain Blood, Pt. 3: The King's Messenger
The Chronicles of Captain Blood, Pt. 4: The Love Story of Jeremy Pitt
The War Indemnity
renewed-contributions.note: Title as given in CCE renewal record. The Sabatini story that appears in this issue is titled 'Ransom' there.

renewed-contributions.title: The Beauty Mask Murder
renewed-contributions.note: This is the last serial installment with a CCE renewal record, but FictionMags reports additional parts in the next 3 issues.

renewed-contributions.title: Gallows Key
renewed-contributions.note: Title as given in issue.  CCE renewal record gives title as 'Gallow's Key'.

renewed-contributions.title: Back Streets
renewed-contributions.note: Title as given in issue.  First CCE renewal record gives title as 'Back Street'; there is also a later CCE renewal record for this part giving the correct title.

renewed-contributions.title: The Expiation of Madame de Coulevain
renewed-contributions.note: Title as given in issue.  CCE renewal record gives title as 'The Expiation of Mme. Coulevain'.

renewed-contributions.title: Fine Gold (Lifeboat)
renewed-contributions.title-note: Title as given in CCE renewal record.  Issue table of contents gives title as 'In a Lifeboat' and the header of the story's first page in the issue gives title as 'Lifeboat'.

renewed-contributions.title: Back Streets
renewed-contributions.note: Title as given in issue.  CCE renewal record gives title as 'Back Street'.

renewed-contributions.title: The Gratitude of M. de Coulevain
renewed-contributions.note: Title as given in issue.  CCE renewal record gives title as 'The Gratitude of M. Decoulevain'.

renewed-contributions.title: Back Streets
renewed-contributions.note: Title as given in issue.  CCE renewal record gives title as 'Back Street'.

Back Streets
renewed-contributions.note: Title as given in issue.  CCE renewal record gives title as 'Back Street'.

renewed-contributions.note: Title as given in issue.  CCE renewal record gives title as 'Back Street'.

renewed-contributions.title: Ukridge and the Home From Home
The Gay Bandit of the Border
Back Streets
renewed-contributions.note: Title as given in issue.  CCE renewal record gives title as 'Back Street'.

renewed-contributions.title: The Gay Bandit of the Border
Back Streets
renewed-contributions.note: Title as given in issue.  CCE renewal record gives title as 'Back Street'.

renewed-contributions.title: But What About Mrs. Paul Revere?
Men Dislike Women
renewed-contributions.note: This is the last CCE renewal record we found for this serialization, though FictionMags says an additional part was published in the May issue. The CCE also has a renewal for a book with the same title and author.

renewed-contributions.title: The Gay Bandit of the Border
The Gay Bandit of the Border
The Right Thing is the Kind Thing
Business Man
renewed-contributions.note: Title as given in CCE renewal record. FictionMags gives title as 'A Business Man in Love'. We have not examined the issue in question.

renewed-contributions.title: That Ever-Loving Wife
renewed-contributions.note: Title as given in CCE renewal record. FictionMags gives title as 'That Ever-Loving Wife of Hymie's'.  We have not examined the issue in question.

comment: For contribution renewals, pick up at 1959 Jan-Jun after 'Hearst' check
additional-note: Absorbed Hearst's International in March 1925, and from then until 1952 published as 'Hearst's International and Cosmopolitan' or 'Hearst's International Combined with Cosmopolitan'.  However, 'Cosmopolitan' was the more prominently featured part of the title, and was generally used as the magazine's short title.
